description: From Middle English ussher, uscher, usscher, from Anglo-Norman usser and Old French ussier, uissier (“porter, doorman”) (compare French huissier), from Vulgar Latin *ustiārius (“doorkeeper”), from Latin ōstiārius, from ōstium (“door”). Akin to ōs (“mouth”). Probably a doublet of ostiary and huissier.

entries.meaning: A person, in a church, cinema etc., who escorts people to their seats.
A male escort at a wedding.
(obsolete) An assistant to a head teacher or schoolteacher; an assistant teacher.

verbs.description: usher (third-person singular simple present ushers, present participle ushering, simple past and past participle ushered)

entries.meaning: To guide people to their seats.

examples: Margaret was astonished at the magnificence of the apartments into which she was ushered.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To precede; to act as a forerunner or herald.
examples: Thus the Harvard poets and wits ushered The New England Courant out of existence.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, transitive) To lead or guide somewhere.
